title: Will Afghanistan's parliamentary elections be held as scheduled on 15 October 2016?
preds: Have you found any sources claiming there wouldn't be an election held then?
Incremental adjustment down for the passage of time.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

CNN, October 3, 'Taliban launches major assault on Afghan city of Kunduz': http://www.cnn.com/2016/10/03/middleeast/taliban-afghanistan-kunduz/
Clips from CNN article:
"Heavy fighting is still going on," Ehsanullah Sadiqi told CNN, speaking by phone from Kunduz.
He said traumatic memories are still fresh for much of the city's population after the Taliban capture of Kunduz in late September 2015.
"A lot of people who fled Kunduz last year at this time when the Taliban had taken over the city returned to Kunduz. So the number of people trying to flee again today was huge," Sadiqi said. He described city streets that are almost completely deserted.

Deutsche Well, August 18, 'Discord between Afghan unity government leaders intensifies - Calls for fresh elections have intensified in Afghanistan as the unity government leaders fail to resolve their dispute over power sharing. President Ghani and CEO Abdullah have yet to find a way to work in tandem.': http://www.dw.com/en/discord-between-afghan-unity-government-leaders-intensifies/a-19485299
Clips from DW article:
"Meanwhile, opposition leaders have called for Ghani and Abdullah to step down, chiding the leaders for their failure to realize electoral reforms necessary to pave the way for parliamentary and district council elections.
"We must hold fresh elections and elect a new president to break the deadlock," Anwar Ulhaq Ahadi, an opposition leader, said Wednesday, August 17.
Fakor, however, believes that the main issue is not the agreement between the two leaders but their track record so far in power. "They have failed to work together. This makes people speculate that Afghanistan is heading for early elections."

Much of the opposition to the autumn election can be traced to the palpable anger that still lingers from the 2014 presidential campaign (¶ 15-17).

The compromise brokered by the US government in 2014 relative to the outcome of the presidential election now reaches a deadline exists linked to the reform of the Afghan electoral processes (Katzman, 2016).

I've been high on this one for long enough. The recent acrimonious failure to agree on terms for the Structure Law suggests that Afghanistan has a long way to go before it is comfortable with the democratic process. Will of the people, be damned! What matters more is who gets to govern them. 
I had - optimistically, perhaps - seen these elections as an important step forward for Afghanistan, but I no longer think that. The silence out of Washington and Islamabad has been deafening - or am I missing something?

In it. the key assessment is " Ahmad Yousuf Nuristani, the head of the election commission, told a press conference in Kabul.Nuristani said the elections would only be held on time if the government provided the necessary budget and security for candidates, election personnel and ballot boxes"

@Intriligator's point that there is no precedent for delaying a scheduled and confirmed election is well taken, and the Government's frequent reiteration that the election will take place on the scheduled date, will make it difficult for them to delay without losing face. However, there do appear to be substantial procedural/logistical obstacles, and the selection is more complex than previous ones. Therefore, I think it's somewhat more likely that the election will not take place as scheduled, but I do not have a high degree of confidence. As others have noted, June 17 will be the moment of truth in terms of the publishing of the calendar. I will update then.

this out June 10,2016 crossed my desk.
https://www.afghanistan-analysts.org/pushing-the-parliament-to-accept-a-decree-another-election-without-reform/
"Pushing the Parliament to Accept a Decree: Another Election without Reform?
"Afghanistan’s electoral reform process, that was supposed to be a precondition for the next ballot, has been excruciatingly slow and has culminated in a watered-down version of its original mandate. The delays mean that it has by now become practically impossible to hold elections this year. The presidential palace, however, continues to insist that both elections – for Wolesi Jirga and district councils – will take place in mid-October, as planned, and has increased pressure on parliament to pass a crucial decree. AAN’s Martine van Bijlert and Ali Yawar Adili take a closer look at the intricacies involved, as the parliament prepares to discuss the decree"

The road to elections won't be easy, but at least they're still thinking about them: https://www.khaama.com/parliament-delays-voting-for-presidential-decree-regarding-electoral-reforms-01226
As an aside, "Afghanistan welcomes broader US military role against Taliban" http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/asiapacific/afghanistan-welcomes/2864604.html "The US presidential election is coming up this year and Obama needs to show that the war in Afghanistan is still important," Kabul-based military analyst Wahid Taqat told AFP. "He cannot afford to let Afghanistan fail." I wonder what that actually means - are October's proposed elections part of the success/failure equation, or has the "Global Democratic Revolution" been abandoned post-Iraq?

The following pattern can be seen in previous elections in Afghanistan since 2004.  Each election since 2004 (with this exception - IFP) which has been schedule, has also been confirmed and occurred.   Presidential election 2004, House of Elders 2005, Presidential 2009, House of People 2010, Presidential April 2014, and Presidential June 2014.   Despite the variances (both large and small, in the degree and intensity of military conflicts, insurgencies, Islamist revolts and guerrilla warfare) schedule elections have occurred.   The current election for October 2016, has been schedule and confirmed.   Given the admittedly small N where outcomes in these case were yes, I have no reason so suspect any different (except in the case of a large scale territorial war, uprisings, insurgencies, external interferences and high level of volatility).   This of course does not speak to likely events such as corruption in electioneering, interference and military disruption and bombings by insurgents, or ongoing guerrilla and terror tactics.  Previous elections have occurred under similar and varying degrees of intensity.

The date for the elections is confirmed and scheduled.    Possible military engagements and internal factionalism among various interests could derail the process.  Estimate increased due to confirmed scheduled date.

Based on previous difficulties with holding elections on time, the reduced influence of the west in Afghanistan to ensure the process takes place on time and the decline in the security situation my initial assessment is a 30-39% chance with the end percentage being closer to the lower end of the scale than the higher.

Most of the problems have centered around pre-existing disputes within Afghanistan's coalition government between the two main candidates from the 2014 Presidential election. The overhaul of the Afghan electoral system prior to a new parliamentary election was a key part of the post-election power-sharing deal reached between President Mohammad Ashraf Ghani and Chief Executive Abdullah Abdullah. Whilst both agree in not holding an election before the process is overhauled, there is disagreement on how to proceed and who should oversee the process. Ghani's recommendation of Shukria Barakzai for the post was rejected by Abdullah, who saw her as being too close to Ghani. Simultaneously Abdullah has also been strongly opposed to the same officials overseeing the election as oversaw the 2014 Presidential election, due in part to the widespread belief that Ghani benefited from the 2014 elections irregularities compared to Abdullah. Tying into this is the fact that no officials from the election have been charged with any crime or removed. In contrast to Abdullah's more hardline calls for total overhaul, Ghani's supporters have been more supportive of more limited reforms.

Moderating my position from 10% to 15%.

Dated April 6th, this article reports that Nuristani, appointed to head the IEC by former president Karzai, resigned his position only 3 months after setting the Parliamentary election date.  The election announcement is viewed as political, due to the Karzai appointment.  Nuristani reportedly claimed the gov't was not cooperating on a new election process, yet, needed to provide a budget, ensure security (for polling centers, staff, candidates and voters), and ensure gov't bodies co-operate.  First time district council elections in a large number of constituencies, many insecure, with unclear boundaries and varying district lists are also issues.

Afghanistan is officially scheduled to have the election for House of People (parliament) on October 10, 2016.   Whether is will be delayed or postponed is a somewhat different question.  However, the date is officially confirmed.

AFAIK, the electoral reforms that were supposed to be introduced (part of the compromise forced upon Ghani and Abdullah by John Kerry) have yet to be agreed upon much less implemented. The election date was announced by the Independent Election Commission, whose legitimacy has been consistently challenged by Abdullah's supporters. One of the biggest problems in the last Presidential election was that about 20 million voter ID cards had been issued to an electorate of 12 million, hence allegations of fraud (on both sides) were hardly a surprise. Though I haven't yet found any reports after those in January when the 15 October date was announced, I very much doubt that elections will be held as scheduled. The absence of news is probably telling, as otherwise we should be hearing about preparations. In addition, the Taliban have announced a spring offensive.
This seems to be about the rate at which elections in such places are held as scheduled.  There is no reason to believe it will hold in the case of Afghanistan.  Stay tuned.
